text:
Hey Rebekah, Dave Gerhardt shared an example I really liked on <https://www.patreon.com/davegerhardt|his Patreon> podcast. Essentially, his best-performing cold outreach email at <http://www.drift.com|Drift> abandoned the idea of trying to secure a meeting or call, instead it read (and I'm paraphrasing from memory):

Subject: Only forms?
Body: Hey [name], I was taking a look at your website and noticed you're only using email forms. Is there a particular reason for that?

Dave speculates this performed so well because:
1. It was short and punchy.
2. It captured intrigue ("Only forms? What does he mean only forms? What are the alternatives to forms I don't know about?").
3. It was ultra low friction - all it asked for was an email reply, nothing else.
By aiming for just getting a reply to the email, he could continue the conversation in follow up emails, leading to booking calls/meetings.

That's just one way of doing this - I'm sure there are thousands of email styles that have worked brilliantly for thousands of different people. :slightly_smiling_face:

Dave speculates this performed so well because:
It was short and punchy.
It captured intrigue ("Only forms? What does he mean only forms? What are the alternatives to forms I don't know about?").
It was ultra low friction - all it asked for was an email reply, nothing else.

By aiming for just getting a reply to the email, he could continue the conversation in follow up emails, leading to booking calls/meetings.

That's just one way of doing this - I'm sure there are thousands of email styles that have worked brilliantly for thousands of different people.

text: Hi everyone! Does anyone use SMS marketing to help them attract leads, remind clients of appointments, or promote new services? We use HubSpot as a CRM/CMS and my boss wants to use Chatflow, but I'm not sure if you can also text contacts. :thinking_face: I do know we can connect it to our FB page. I'm familiar with ManyChat, but my boss doesn't want to add any new expenses with their pro plan since we are losing business account from Covid-19 disruptions. Let me know your suggesstions. Thanks! :pray:

elements.text: Hi everyone! Does anyone use SMS marketing to help them attract leads, remind clients of appointments, or promote new services? We use HubSpot as a CRM/CMS and my boss wants to use Chatflow, but I'm not sure if you can also text contacts.

I do know we can connect it to our FB page. I'm familiar with ManyChat, but my boss doesn't want to add any new expenses with their pro plan since we are losing business account from Covid-19 disruptions. Let me know your suggesstions. Thanks!

text: ManyChat is the industry darling, so you'll hear a lot of people recommending it. I've never personally used it, but I hear good things. We personally don't use SMS marketing except when it's integrated into a service we use like Calendly

text: Can anyone provide examples of how their content teams are structured? Particularly for career growth?

elements.text: Can anyone provide examples of how their content teams are structured? Particularly for career growth?

text: I run my own gig, so super interested to hear what others in bigger teams have to say on this :eyes:

elements.text: I run my own gig, so super interested to hear what others in bigger teams have to say on this

text: Thanks, <@UJ53ETCLB>. I've used ManyChat and really like it, but not sure if I can convince them to sign up for a trial. They really don't want to add new expenses even though I'm pretty sure they will see the return. We have about 7k contacts but only about 500 are really engaged. So I wonder if we should message only clients or use it more for promoting new services to our entire list of contacts. My guess is that they want to recoup revenue lost from clients that dropped us recently. :shrug:

text: I'd tread carefully on messaging contacts out of the blue. Make sure you're abiding by the CANSPAM laws, otherwise you could find yourself in a world of hurt :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I'd tread carefully on messaging contacts out of the blue. Make sure you're abiding by the CANSPAM laws, otherwise you could find yourself in a world of hurt

text:
I'm seeing more companies moves away from having a dedicated content team. Ex: during my time at HubSpot, the "content team" restructured several times, the last iteration moved the blog team and lead-gen folks over to Growth, and more editorial content sits on a brand team alongside social (If I'm remember all this correctly).

I'm seeing others adopt a similar approach. I spoke with a marketing VP at a ~50ish person company recently whose marketing team is split by demand gen, product marketing, and brand. Each of those has a content component, but there is no single "content team"

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: At a previous gig (1000+ employees) we split content into “agency” and “creative” Agency = all the stuff where the “client” was someone internal like sales enablement. Creative = editorial work like blog posts, video interviews, etc. where the “client” is the reader / customer

text:
I've spoken with a couple of "writers" at tech companies recently, who work in a vaguely similar approach to what you're both saying, Janessa and Sean.

They act as internal agencies for many teams/functions within the company, supporting where needed.

Interestingly, in both these companies there are also named "content" teams, who they seem to have no overlap with. These "content" teams appear to focus largely on blog-type content, and perhaps some other mediums too.

At GoCardless, where I work, we have "Content" as a team that sits under a broader "Comms" umbrella, which sits within the even broader (broadest?) "Marketing" team. The individuals within this team tend to have separate primary focuses - mine, for instance, is our high-volume blog content (for SEO) and major research reports.

The individuals within this team tend to have separate primary focuses - mine, for instance, is our high-volume blog content (for SEO) and major research reports.

text: our team is currently split into "content" & "demand gen", with content including product marketing, webinars, emails, and long form content. as the SEO manager and primary blog content writer, i'm on demand gen (since it drives ~50% of our free trials and i work v closely with our PPC manager) along with the content specialist i manage who manages our social media. it's an interesting split, but it seems to be going well for us so far

text:
At Sprout we have a content team, which primarily drives strategy and marketing-wide editorial planning, brand content and customer proof (eg case studies), as well as an SEO team that leads our search driven content. The content team or demand gen team usually drive acquisition campaigns, but my team (content) creates the bulk of external materials. 

We also have different “squads” across marketing so members of the content team sit on both Awareness & Perception (social, brand content, events, PR, internal comms) and New Business (SEO, DG, paid social and search, web and marketing ops). Others across the biz play a role in content brainstorming, feedback and supporting with sales collateral/enablement. 

It sounds messy but has actually been a good evolution and solution for us, as long as there is clear communication about goals and priorities at all levels. Happy to talk further if anyone is interested, I love learning about other teams’ setups.

elements.text: At Sprout we have a content team, which primarily drives strategy and marketing-wide editorial planning, brand content and customer proof (eg case studies), as well as an SEO team that leads our search driven content. The content team or demand gen team usually drive acquisition campaigns, but my team (content) creates the bulk of external materials.

We also have different “squads” across marketing so members of the content team sit on both Awareness & Perception (social, brand content, events, PR, internal comms) and New Business (SEO, DG, paid social and search, web and marketing ops). Others across the biz play a role in content brainstorming, feedback and supporting with sales collateral/enablement.

It sounds messy but has actually been a good evolution and solution for us, as long as there is clear communication about goals and priorities at all levels. Happy to talk further if anyone is interested, I love learning about other teams’ setups.
